lead_paragraph: Two days after a female aviator went on national television with the story of how she was molested and manhandled at a naval aviators' convention and how little had been done to investigate the event, the White House apparently decided it was time to act. On Friday, President Bush had called the aviator, Lieut. Paula Coughlin, in for a meeting at the White House during which he and his wife, Barbara, expressed their sympathy and assured her that there would be a full investigation, a White House spokesman said today.

snippet: The Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) has elected a woman as president, the first for the 770,000-member Protestant denomination. The Rev. Sharon E. Watkins, senior pastor at Disciples Christian Church in Bartlesville, Okla., was overwhelming...
lead_paragraph: The Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) has elected a woman as president, the first for the 770,000-member Protestant denomination. The Rev. Sharon E. Watkins, senior pastor at Disciples Christian Church in Bartlesville, Okla., was overwhelmingly elected to a six-year term on Tuesday at the denomination's General Assembly in Portland, Ore. ''Today is not about me,'' Ms. Watkins, 51, said. ''Its about all of us joining together and letting God work with us and through us.'' A graduate of Phillips Theological Seminary and Yale Divinity School, Ms. Watkins succeeds the Rev. William Chris Hobgood.

headline.main: National Briefing | Religion: Denomination Elects First Female President

Watts, President of the American Female Guardian Society and Home for the Friendless, has been sued by a former teacher in one of the schools maintained by that institution for slander and libel. The former teacher, Elizabeth Foley, wants $10,000 damages, declaring that Mrs. Watts has kept her from obtaining any other position.
abstract: Sued by Elizabeth Foley for Slander; Dismissed

headline.main: FORMER TEACHER SUES MRS. HELEN W. WATTS; Latter Is President of American Female Guardian Society. Miss Elizabeth Foley Wants $10,000 for Alleged Slander Which Prevents Her Obtaining Any Position.

snippet: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. On Nov. 6 of this past year, Matina Horner, a 33-year-old associate professor of psychology at Harvard University, became the sixth president of Radcliffe College, the famed school for women founded in 1879 across the Cambridge Co...
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. On Nov. 6 of this past year, Matina Horner, a 33-year-old associate professor of psychology at Harvard University, became the sixth president of Radcliffe College, the famed school for women founded in 1879 across the Cambridge Common from Harvard. For great numbers of people--both inside and outside of the academic world -- Matina Horner's inauguration was a moment of ritual rather than of ceremony,
